content.text:
Energy governance is essential for guiding a just transition, aiming to minimize the negative impacts of climate policies while maximizing social benefits for diverse groups, including local communities, women, youth, and workers.
This endeavour entails alleviating social pressures on affected communities and harnessing the energy transition as a driver for empowerment, development, and equal opportunities, ensuring that no one is left behind. Central to this effort are government policies, regulations, and incentives, which play a pivotal role in addressing distributional impacts and mitigating risks associated with the energy transition, thus fostering economic, social, and political development.

content.title: GOVERNANCE STRATEGIES FOR A JUST ENERGY TRANSITION

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

The current energy crisis offers an opportunity to accelerate the shift to renewable energy and build stable, secure, and just societies through accountable, inclusive governance. Achieving this requires the right institutional arrangements, policies, business models, technologies, innovations, and infrastructure to enable effective system-wide transformation.
This lesson explores key energy governance strategies employed by UNDP, introduces the concept of energy democracy, and highlights practical examples.

A just energy transition necessitates a comprehensive, integrated approach that permeates all energy planning processes and effectively navigates through the complex and intersecting challenges inherent in the transition. This holistic approach finds expression in system-wide mobilizations, spanning multilateral environmental settings, social protection policies, social dialogue, human rights, and fiscal policies. (Scheer, Chan & Hizliok, 2023)

To facilitate a just energy transition, governments must coordinate and actively participate in collective action and transparently engage with local stakeholders, fostering robust collaboration between institutions.

This collaborative endeavour can engender an international environment conducive to peer pressure and leadership in energy transition. Multilateral environmental governance, for instance, fosters accountability among actors by encouraging countries to increase their designated Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), as outlined in the Paris Agreement (Averchenkova & Chan, 2023).
Prior to 2023, the principles of just energy transition were already embedded in 38% of NDCs and 56% of long-term strategies (LTS), underscoring a growing recognition of the importance of equity and inclusivity in climate action (UNFCCC, 2023). Effective governance strategies must uphold these principles, ensuring that the transition to clean energy benefits all members of society, with a commitment to leaving no one behind.

Addressing the distributional consequences of climate action presents a significant challenge, characterized by uncertainty in net benefits and the distribution of costs and benefits among different stakeholders. Developing countries face a particularly daunting task as they grapple with the need for hard data to anticipate changes and demonstrate the overwhelming benefits of transitioning to a green economy. This transition holds promise not only for environmental sustainability but also for achieving a just transition for society as a whole.
To bridge this data gap and facilitate evidence-based just transition planning, the UNDP's Climate Promise initiative has been instrumental in guiding countries. Through qualitative and quantitative assessments, including modelling techniques, countries can estimate the impacts of NDCs on key socioeconomic indicators such as GDP, employment, skills, income distribution, and gender equality. These assessments enable countries to gain insights into the distributional impacts of NDCs and identify targeted measures to ensure a just transition, particularly for vulnerable populations such as women and informal workers.

For instance, in Nigeria and Zimbabwe, national green jobs assessments conducted using the Green Jobs Assessment Model (GJAM) have informed the development of NDCs and just transition roadmaps.
Similarly, in Türkiye, the GJAM was utilized to analyse the potential effects of reducing coal's share in electricity production and increasing investments in wind and solar energy. Building upon this foundational work, efforts are underway to expand the scope of assessments to encompass broader socioeconomic implications associated with implementing NDCs and LTS.
In Serbia, for example, a qualitative baseline analysis was undertaken as part of a just transition study focusing on coal-intensive regions and communities. This study, informed by international best practices, provides an overview of key considerations and offers a comprehensive seven-step roadmap along with follow-up actions to ensure a just transition.
By leveraging such assessments and strategies, countries can navigate the complexities of transitioning to a green economy while leaving no one behind, thereby fostering sustainable development and social equity.

Governments bear the primary responsibility for establishing the requisite policy frameworks to expedite a just transition and facilitate social dialogue. Such policy support encompasses the formulation of social protection policies necessary to accommodate labour market adjustments, enhance job quality and incomes, and promote equity and social inclusion. This entails the provision of welfare safety nets and adequate compensation for individuals, communities, and regions adversely affected by planned policies.
Investment in human and institutional capital training assumes paramount importance as policy complexity escalates. Equipping stakeholders with the necessary skills and knowledge to navigate evolving policy landscapes effectively and fostering south-south cooperation are key to facilitating the sharing of best practices and experiences across countries and regions, thereby bolstering institutional capacities and policy integration for a just transition.

For instance, in Belize, UNDP is actively engaged in bolstering the capacities of Small- and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) to access green technology, digitalization, and innovation. Empowering SMEs with the tools and resources needed to embrace sustainable practices contributes to fostering a conducive environment for green entrepreneurship and economic diversification. Through targeted support and collaboration, governments, alongside organizations like UNDP, can spearhead efforts to foster inclusive and sustainable development in alignment with the principles of a just transition.
The patchwork of international and transnational initiatives underscores the need for greater coherence to foster responsible, sustainable, and transparent supply chains. While there has been a growing recognition of the challenges associated with the critical materials supply chain, the proliferation of voluntary initiatives and regulatory frameworks by governments, businesses, and civil society groups has resulted in a fragmented landscape of standards. This fragmentation risks sowing confusion among stakeholders and underscores the imperative for enhanced visibility and coherence.

A renewables-based energy transition offers the opportunity to redefine the legacy of extractive industries. Stronger international cooperation is necessary to raise and enforce standards, while longer-term corporate views are essential for sustainable development and earning social license. By addressing these challenges and embracing sustainable practices, the renewable energy transition can pave the way for a more equitable and environmentally conscious future (UNDP, 2022).

UNDP's JET Strategy for Africa emphasizes effective governance mechanisms by taking a system thinking and human right based approach and encourages multi-stakeholder dialogues, introducing innovative policies and regulations, strengthening institutions, and ensuring inclusive participation and decision-making that leaves no one behind.

By promoting renewable energy deployment and reducing dependence on fossil fuels through practical evidence-based approaches, UNDP aims to drive a transformative energy transition that puts people in the centre while simultaneously contributing to all energy related SDGs such as industrial development, water, climate, health, education, gender equality, economic growth, and partnerships. To ensure that energy transition is fair and just even in the case of continuously changing circumstances, UNDP supports the participatory and foresight governance approaches that are responsive and adapt policies as needed and strive for an inclusive and equitable energy system that benefits all members of society.
Digital Tools and Community Participation

Digital technologies have emerged as a powerful tool to support equitable transitions in regions reliant on coal. In South Africa, digital platforms are empowering communities to have a voice in their post-coal future. Youth in coal-mining areas have leveraged mobile micro-surveys to collect data on the impacts of mine closures, the prospects of future employment, and their understanding of the Just Transition process. These insights, gathered directly from affected communities, are instrumental in shaping inclusive policies and creating new opportunities for sustainable development. Furthermore, applications such as the Land Use Repurposing Application (LURA) help communities collaboratively identify development opportunities at former coal sites, guiding investments toward green job creation and economic diversification.

content.title:
Case Study RBA:
Modelling the employment Impacts of Energy Policies to Guide NDC Enhancement and a Just Transition

content.text:
In the energy transition, jobs are both created and lost, making it vital to model Low Emission Development Strategies (LEDS) to assess their impacts on the job market and GDP. Such assessments are crucial for preparing social safety nets and income support to mitigate negative impacts.
Zimbabwe, a signatory to the Paris Agreement, has developed Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to combat climate change. Zimbabwe relies primarily on coal power, the largest emitter in the power sector, and hydropower. Solar and wind contributions are minimal, and policies aim to increase their share. Biomass is mainly used in unclean cooking methods, posing health risks, especially to women and children.

The project's findings highlighted the importance of assessing the green energy job market to adjust strategies and policies to prevent unemployment. Measures should be implemented to support individuals who may lose jobs post-construction. Additionally, the study emphasized the need to account for emissions during the construction phase of green energy projects, despite their ultimate contribution to emission reduction. Inclusive stakeholder engagement is crucial for a just energy transition. Excluding stakeholders from policy formulation can lead to implementation challenges and potential policy failure. It is recommended to involve stakeholders throughout the process to ensure effective and sustainable outcomes.
Key policy recommendations from this study include developing an industrialization policy to support the manufacture of renewable energy products, reducing imports, and creating more job opportunities. Capacity development strategies should be implemented to enhance human capital to execute the massive projects intended for the green revolution.

One of the primary challenges encountered during this project was data availability. To address this, proxy data was used, though it may lead to conclusions not fully aligned with the country under study. In today's digital age, data plays a crucial role in effective energy modeling. Therefore, it is essential for governments to invest in data capture, storage, and processing infrastructure. Using a modeling tool in similar projects enhances replicability across different contexts. However, the key factor for replication is data availability.
This project shed light on overlooked areas in developing strategies and policies for the energy transition. It contributes to policy development and assessment, ensuring alignment with sustainable energy development goals.
UNDERSTANDING THE EMPLOYMENT IMPLICATIONS

To understand the employment implications of transitioning energy technologies, both quantitative and qualitative analyses are essential.
Quantitative analysis examines changes in employment levels, considering direct, indirect, and induced jobs.
Direct jobs relate to specific energy projects, such as construction and operations.
Indirect jobs include those related to supplying materials for energy projects.
Induced jobs are created when workers spend their income.
Qualitative analysis moves beyond the sheer number of jobs to consider job quality, including salary levels, job security, and skill requirements.
New jobs may may require shifting regions or sectors, and the longevity of jobs also varies, impacting the overall socioeconomic landscape. 
References:
[1] UNFCC (2021). Zimbabwe Revised Nationally Determined Contribution
[2] UNDP (2021). Measuring the Socioeconomic Impacts of Climate Policies to Guide NDC Enhancement and a Just Transition

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

cards.title: Governance Must Prioritize Equity and Inclusion in Energy Transitions
cards.description: Effective energy governance requires a holistic, system-wide approach that integrates social, economic, and environmental dimensions. By embedding principles of equity and inclusivity in policies, such as Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and long-term strategies, governments can ensure that the benefits of the energy transition are distributed fairly, particularly for vulnerable groups like women, youth, and informal workers.

cards.title: Data-Driven Strategies are Essential for Just Transition Planning
cards.description: Bridging the data gap through tools like the Green Jobs Assessment Model (GJAM) enables countries to anticipate the socioeconomic impacts of climate policies. By conducting qualitative and quantitative assessments, governments can identify targeted measures to mitigate adverse effects and maximize benefits, ensuring that no one is left behind in the transition to a green economy.

cards.title: Energy Democracy Empowers Communities and Redefines Energy Systems
cards.description: The concept of energy democracy emphasizes participatory decision-making and equitable access to energy resources. By fostering inclusive governance and empowering marginalized communities, energy democracy challenges traditional power structures and promotes a more sustainable and just energy system that operates in the public interest.
